deliberation: This verse is mainly a dating formula, which is literal. The only potentially figurative element is the standard prophetic idiom 'the word of YHWH came to me', in which an abstract 'word' is described as coming, which personifies the divine message.

deliberation: Verse 2 is highly figurative: Pharaoh is likened to a 'young lion of the nations' and to a sea-monster/dragon in the seas, and his political disruption is described as stirring and muddying waters with his feet. I treat the lion image, the sea-monster image, and the water-muddying as three distinct though related figures.

instances.hebrew_text: וַתָּ֣גַח בְּנַהֲרוֹתֶ֗יךָ וַתִּדְלַח־מַ֙יִם֙ בְּרַגְלֶ֔יךָ וַתִּרְפֹּ֖ס נַהֲרוֹתָֽם

deliberation: This continues the sea‑monster imagery by introducing a fishing‑net scene: God spreads a net over Pharaoh and hauls him up via a multitude of peoples. This is one coherent metaphor for divine judgment through invading nations.

deliberation: Imagery of casting the creature on the land and having birds and beasts feed on it extends the monster‑capture metaphor. Though such corpses being eaten by animals could be literally conceivable, here it functions as a symbolic picture of utter disgrace and defeat.

deliberation: The verse continues corpse imagery in exaggerated spatial terms: flesh on mountains and filling valleys with his 'height'. This is hyperbolic metaphor for vast slaughter and disgrace.

deliberation: Blood flooding the land and filling channels is vivid and obviously excessive in scale. This is hyperbolic sacrificial‑battlefield imagery emphasizing the horror of judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהִשְׁקֵיתִ֨י אֶ֧רֶץ צָפָֽתְךָ֛ מִדָּמְךָ֖ אֶל־הֶהָרִ֑ים וַאֲפִקִ֖ים יִמָּלְא֥וּן מִמֶּֽךָּ

prophetic alarm
instances.explanation: Egypt’s defeat is envisioned as producing so much blood that it drenches the land and fills channels, an intentional hyperbole to convey catastrophic slaughter.

deliberation: This verse uses cosmic‑darkening motifs: the heavens covered, stars darkened, sun veiled, moon not shining, coordinated with Pharaoh’s extinction. This is a standard metaphor in prophetic literature for massive political catastrophe.

instances.hebrew_text: וְכִסֵּיתִ֤י בְכַבּֽוֹתְךָ֙ שָׁמַ֔יִם וְהִקְדַּרְתִּ֖י אֶת־כֹּֽכְבֵיהֶ֑ם שֶׁ֚מֶשׁ בֶּעָנָ֣ן אֲכַסֶּ֔נּוּ וְיָרֵ֖חַ לֹא־יָאִ֥יר אוֹרֽוֹ

deliberation: Verse 8 continues the darkening motif: all lights in the heavens are darkened and darkness is placed on Egypt’s land. This is metaphorical, forming part of the same cosmic‑judgment imagery, with hyperbolic scope.

deliberation: Here God says He will 'vex the hearts' of many peoples by bringing Egypt’s breaking among the nations. The key figurative piece is 'hearts' for inner emotions, a conventional metonymy, within an otherwise straightforward description of political shock.

deliberation: God’s 'brandishing My sword before them' is a key anthropomorphic metaphor: divine judgment is portrayed as a warrior lifting a sword, even though the historical instrument is Babylon’s army. The fear and trembling reactions are literal emotional responses.

awe‑inspiring, confrontational
instances.explanation: Though historically realized through the Babylonian campaign, God depicts His judgment as personally brandishing a sword before the nations, using warrior imagery as a metaphor and the sword metonymically for warfare.

deliberation: This verse names 'the sword of the king of Babylon' as coming upon Egypt. The sword stands metonymically for Babylon’s military might and campaign, the primary figurative element here.

instances.explanation: The ‘sword’ functions as a metonymy for the Babylonian king’s armed forces and their destructive campaign against Egypt.

deliberation: Two metonymic expressions appear: 'by the swords of warriors' (swords for warfare/warriors) and 'the splendor/pride of Egypt' for the nation’s power and glory. Both are standard but still figurative.

instances.explanation: Egypt’s 'splendor/pride' is a metonym for its glory and status; to plunder it is to strip away its honor and arrogance.

deliberation: This verse describes the removal of cattle from abundant waters and that no human foot or animal hoof will muddy them. It can be read quite literally as cessation of economic/livestock activity. The muddying motif echoes earlier river imagery but here does not introduce a new, distinct figurative device.

Here the waters of Egypt are said to be made to settle and the rivers will 'go like oil'. This simile suggests unnaturally smooth, sluggish water, symbolizing cessation of activity and perhaps life; it is a clear figurative comparison.

somber, descriptive
instances.explanation: The rivers flowing 'like oil' is a simile evoking unnaturally smooth and sluggish waters, figuratively portraying a stilled, lifeless Egypt after judgment.

deliberation: The verse speaks of making the land of Egypt desolate, 'a land from its fullness' (emptied of what filled it). 'Fullness' functions metonymically for inhabitants and resources, though the wording overall can be read fairly literally.

shared mapping between physical fullness and socio‑economic vitality
abundance vs. desolation

presents desolation as the inverse of former fullness
contrastive, didactic
instances.explanation: The 'fullness' of the land metonymically refers to its inhabitants and riches; their removal makes the land desolate.

deliberation: This verse labels the composition as a 'dirge' and speaks literally of its being sung by 'the daughters of the nations'. These are generic genre and performer references; there is no clear figurative expression beyond normal poetic terminology.
Like verse 1, this is a dating formula introducing a new oracle. Again, the only figurative element is the standard phrase 'the word of YHWH came to me', personifying the divine message.

instances.english_text: the word of GOD came to me

supports the authority of the message

instances.explanation: As in v.1, the abstract 'word' is treated as an agent that 'comes', a conventional prophetic personification and metonymy.

deliberation: The verse commands a lament over Egypt’s multitude and to 'bring them down' to the 'lowest parts of the earth' with those going down to the Pit. This uses underworld/Pit imagery as a spatial metaphor for death and national demise.

instances.english_text: to the lowest part of the earth, among those who have gone down into the Pit

leveling, demythologizing
instances.explanation: The 'lowest parts of the earth' and 'the Pit' are idiomatic images for the underworld; to go down there is to die and lose one’s place in the land of the living, here applied to Egypt’s political demise.

deliberation: This verse is a sharp rhetorical question about Egypt’s beauty and a command to go down and lie with the uncircumcised. Though 'beauty' may implicitly refer to Egypt’s splendor, the language is essentially straightforward mockery of Egypt’s supposed superiority, without a distinct new figurative image.

The main figurative expression is again 'the sword' standing for the act of killing/warfare. The lying in the midst of the slain is literal within the death motif; 'sword given, draw her' is a compact way to speak of execution by war.

vehicle: חֶרֶב / sword that is given and drawn

instances.explanation: The 'sword' functions as metonymy for the violent means of Egypt’s downfall—warfare and execution by enemy forces.

deliberation: This verse describes mighty warriors speaking from the midst of Sheol to Pharaoh and his helpers. The overall descent‑to‑Sheol scene is a metaphorical portrayal of death as existence in an underworld community; here the emphasis is on that underworld society commenting on Pharaoh’s fate.

shared notion of a realm where the dead are gathered and aware of new arrivals
communal disgrace after death

reinforces the leveling of all proud empires in death
ironic, humbling
instances.explanation: The depiction of Sheol as a populated realm of speaking warriors is part of a metaphorical underworld scene that communicates the humiliation of once‑great kings, including Pharaoh.

deliberation: This verse states 'Assyria is there with all her company' and describes their graves. 'Assyria' standing for Assyrians, especially its armies and rulers, is metonymic, but otherwise the underworld scene is continued without a new major image.

instances.english_text: Assyria is there with all her company

didactic, comparative
instances.explanation: The proper name 'Assyria' stands metonymically for its company of people now in the realm of the dead.

deliberation: The graves are said to be in the 'farthest recesses of the Pit', and these are those who 'put terror in the land of the living'. 'Land of the living' is an idiomatic merism for the present human world; 'terror' likewise stands for the dread they inspired. I focus on 'land of the living' as the clearer figurative idiom.

instances.english_text: they who struck terror in the land of the living

shared binary of living land vs. underworld
life vs. death realms
posture: emphasizes that those who once dominated the living world are now confined to its opposite, the Pit
underscores the reversal from feared to forgotten
ironic reversal
instances.explanation: The 'land of the living' is an idiomatic expression (a kind of merism) for the entire realm of human life on earth, contrasted with the Pit of the dead.

deliberation: Elam’s fate is described similarly: they 'put their terror in the land of the living' and now 'bear their shame' with those going down to the Pit. I treat 'bear their shame' as a distinct metaphor: shame conceptualized as a load carried with them.

moralizing, punitive
instances.explanation: Elam is said to 'bear their shame', turning shame into a figurative burden they carry along with those who go down to the Pit.

instances.english_text: who struck terror in the land of the living

instances.explanation: Elam’s 'terror' in the 'land of the living' combines metonymy (terror for military might) with the idiom for the present human world.

deliberation: Three related but distinct images appear: (1) a 'bed' made for her among the slain, (2) their 'terror' in the land of the living, and (3) 'bearing their shame' with those who go down to the Pit. I treat each as a separate figurative expression.

instances.explanation: The grave among the slain is metaphorically described as a 'bed', turning death into a kind of grim resting place.
